Text: Considering the impact Silicon Valley has on our lives, I’m surprised how rarely pop culture gets it right. To understand how it works today, you should watch @SiliconHBO. Personally, I identify most with Richard Hendricks: https://b-gat.es/2Q4IEnO pic.twitter.com/5agUIEUdF2
These six toilets could change the world: https://b-gat.es/2Bc5Msh  #WorldToiletDaypic.twitter.com/DKeMC4hokn
The future is bright for the world’s poorest farmers because of innovative companies like @myAgroFarms: https://b-gat.es/2K3PCUF pic.twitter.com/UKCfFKT3b5
I’ve been impressed by @CapriaVC’s work over the last several years and applaud @VulcanInc's investment in the firm.https://b-gat.es/2DmdXDQ
Well said, @MaxCRoser. Being an optimist doesn’t mean you ignore tragedy.https://b-gat.es/2Q0tPCH

Farm yields in many parts of Africa are just a fifth of those in the United States. Innovations in agriculture will make it possible for poor farmers to increase their yields: https://b-gat.es/2PYcUkd pic.twitter.com/49j1LEo4fA

Whenever I travel for the foundation, the farmers I meet talk about one thing that holds them back: they can’t save their money. @myAgroFarms is one of the companies working on creative solutions to this problem.https://b-gat.es/2DlCtoI
I just shared the stage with a beaker of poop in China. Seriously. Here's why: https://b-gat.es/2D8QwxI pic.twitter.com/FEvtEI7wWB

There are few things I love talking about more than toilets.pic.twitter.com/rQdY3ZiIpC

Climate change may be the toughest problem humanity has ever faced — but it's solvable. Washington has a unique opportunity to lead the way as a hub for innovation on clean energy. I urge you to vote yes on 1631. Ballots must be in the mail by Tuesday.https://b-gat.es/2PEzyOe
A compelling look at how advocates and energy sector leaders are working together to tackle the real drivers of climate change.https://b-gat.es/2PGVxUG

I’m at @Stanford today to talk about energy innovation. To prevent the worst effects of climate change, we need to get to zero net greenhouse gas emissions in every sector of the economy within 50 years. Here’s how we can do it: https://b-gat.es/2PFvayq  #StanfordGEFpic.twitter.com/7Mk8Plxu0V
Thailand’s “Mr. Condom” has taught people that there is no reason to be shy about talking about sexual health: https://b-gat.es/2RofcGm pic.twitter.com/AsnIIT6pEm
Can we end extreme poverty? I believe we can get close.https://b-gat.es/2RmYVRU
Technology is not an end in itself. What matters is how we use it to enhance people’s opportunities.  As @melindagates writes in @CNN,  that’s where the magic happens.https://b-gat.es/2PrOjDZ

In a country where most people were uneasy discussing sex, Mechai Viravaidya pushed the conversation out into the open. Thanks to his efforts, Thailand became one of the first countries to achieve a decline in HIV infections: https://b-gat.es/2PvBBEq pic.twitter.com/7238ZgMMN5

When people in Thailand want a condom, they don’t call it a condom. Instead, they refer to it by the name of the man who taught them the importance of using one: https://b-gat.es/2O8Aiq3 pic.twitter.com/EI7hGVvYYU

Rwanda’s health system has become a model for other nations to follow. The country’s example should inspire all leaders to renew their commitments to primary health care. #Astana2018pic.twitter.com/qox6K2iHmv

In his home country, “The Condom King” doesn’t need an introduction. Mechai Viravaidya’s extraordinary life and work in global health has helped improve the lives of millions of people in Thailand.https://b-gat.es/2JePLnC
A polio-free future is within reach. @TVAshleigh is hosting @Rotary’s #WorldPolioDay event to highlight the road ahead. Here’s how to tune-in now.https://b-gat.es/2JgQ3KS
We must take bold steps to end polio for good. Two of the leaders of in this effort, @RotaryRassin and @DrTedros, share what it will take to finish the job. #WorldPolioDayhttps://b-gat.es/2JcnzBT

As long as polio exists anywhere, it is a threat to children everywhere. The progress that we’ve made is thanks to the heroic efforts of health workers, governments, partners, and donors who are working to reach every child. 
#WorldPolioDaypic.twitter.com/LGud5DlJPh

Few people tell stories as well as Melinda. Whenever she gets back from a trip, I always love hearing her talk about the places she went and the people she met. That’s one of the reasons why I’m excited about her new book.https://b-gat.es/2EGmL9W

I try to visit India at least once a year, and every time I’m excited by something new that our foundation’s partners are working on. Here are a few notable updates from the @BMGFIndia team: https://b-gat.es/2EEWIzQ  #StrongerTogetherpic.twitter.com/UhuY9eFdLW

Over the next year, I will be writing a lot about the effort to stop climate change. If you’re interested in a first look at what I’m reading and learning, join the Gates Notes community: https://b-gat.es/2PdPdnx pic.twitter.com/N893OYdNyz
In my home state, climate change is on the ballot. Here’s why I’m voting @Yeson1631 and why I’m encouraging my fellow Washingtonians to do the same.https://b-gat.es/2EBrhGC

If all the cattle in the world joined together to start their own country, they would be the third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases. Here are four more mind-blowing facts about climate change: https://b-gat.es/2PaHLK0 pic.twitter.com/m45HNVmWIG
We need the world’s brightest minds working on preventing the worst effects of climate change. I’m placing my bets in five key areas: https://b-gat.es/2AhPyxd pic.twitter.com/i3K7L9SpFF

How many drivers would have to switch to electric cars to equal the annual emissions saved by replacing one coal power plant with a nuclear plant? Check your answer here and see if you can beat my score on the rest of this climate change quiz: https://b-gat.es/2Agd0es

I hate mosquitoes. The diseases they spread kill more than half a million people every year. In fact, mosquitoes kill more people in one day than sharks kill in 100 years: https://b-gat.es/2L6kRNQ  #WorldMosquitoDaypic.twitter.com/j6DB4yZ4m9
Kofi Annan was one of the great peacemakers of our time. I was fortunate to have the opportunity to work with him on many occasions. I’m sad to learn of his death.pic.twitter.com/VM9QJyzaT3
If you want to understand why this matters, I highly recommend the new book “Capitalism Without Capital” by @haskelecon and @stianwestlake. Here’s my review:https://b-gat.es/2Mg5ffZ

The portion of the global economy that doesn’t fit the old model just keeps getting larger. But the rules that govern the economy haven’t kept up. This is one of the biggest trends in the global economy that isn’t getting enough attention.

Unlike the goods that powered our economy in the past, software is an intangible asset -- “something you can’t touch.” And it’s not the only example: data, insurance, e-books, even movies work in similar ways.
But software doesn’t work like this. Microsoft might spend a lot of money to develop the first unit of a new program, but every unit after that is virtually free to produce.
This chart assumes that the total cost of production increases as supply increases. When a car company makes a new vehicle, the 10th car costs the same to manufacture as the 1000th.
At the time I was in college, this was basically how the global economy worked...pic.twitter.com/2polaSbsXY

14/ This is an amazing time to be alive. I hope you make the most of it.
13/ This is the core of my worldview. It sustains me in tough times and is the reason I love my work. I think it can do same for you.
12/ It doesn’t mean you ignore the serious problems we face. It just means you believe they can be solved.
11/ That matters because if you think the world is getting better, you want to spread the progress to more people and places.
10/ @SAPinker shows how the world is getting better. Sounds crazy, but it’s true. This is the most peaceful time in human history.
9/ If I could give each of you a graduation present, it would be this--the most inspiring book I've ever read.pic.twitter.com/P67BuvpELJ
8/ Like @WarrenBuffett I measure my happiness by whether people close to me are happy and love me, & by the difference I make for others.
7/ Meanwhile, surround yourself with people who challenge you, teach you, and push you to be your best self. As @MelindaGates does for me.
6/ You know more than I did when I was your age. You can start fighting inequity, whether down the street or around the world, sooner.
5/ I also have one big regret: When I left school, I knew little about the world’s worst inequities. Took me decades to learn.
4/ E.g. Intelligence takes many different forms. It is not one-dimensional. And not as important as I used to think.
3/ Looking back on when I left college, there are some things I wish I had known.
2/ AI, energy, and biosciences are promising fields where you can make a huge impact. It's what I would do if starting out today.
